image.altText: Empty liquor bottles and cans lay in the dry Todd River.

props.synopsis: People drinking alcohol in public could be fined more than $900 and arrested under new "nuisance public drinking" rules set to become law in the Northern Territory next week.

title.children: NT police will soon have powers to fine and arrest people for illegal public drinking. Here's how the laws will change

image.altText: Smiling man and woman in akubara, child sits on slide, baby in woman's arms, houses and lawn behind.

props.synopsis: This family lives a bumpy four-hour drive away from medical help. They couldn't do it without the Royal Flying Doctors Service.

title.children: When Lil started bleeding on her bathroom floor, help was hours away. Then the flying doctors arrived

image.altText: A multi-storey office building behind a fence.

props.synopsis: The heads of the NT's peak legal bodies have expressed their "collective grave concern" at the impact of Legal Aid's impending service cuts, in a letter sent to the NT Attorney-General.

title.children: Powerful legal bodies warn Legal Aid NT service cuts will cause 'chaos and uncertainty'

image.altText: A family at Uluru

props.synopsis: The Clausens are one of many Australian families hitting the road and homeschooling their kids along the way. They're part of a growing trend of families moving away from mainstream education.

title.children: Ali and Aaron are 'travel schooling' their son. They say he's learning more outside the classroom

image.altText: a smiling woman

props.synopsis: Stephanie Ryan and eight-year-old Raven died in a townhouse fire east of Brisbane on Sunday.

title.children: Babysitter killed in townhouse fire remembered for her willingness to help others

image.altText: Man with cowboy hat walks out of court with lawyer

props.synopsis: The prosecution and defence have delivered their closing submissions in a judge-only trial of former Darwin City councillor Paul Arnold, who has pleaded not guilty to a string of charges stemming from incidents involving his former partner.

title.children: Final arguments heard in trial of former Darwin councillor accused of DVO breach, stalking

image.altText: A rickshaw in Bangladesh is cycled through flood waters covering the frame with a passenger in tow.

props.synopsis: A study of scenarios where the world temporarily exceeds 1.5C of warming raises concerns for effects that may not be reversible for decades — or longer.

title.children: Temporarily overshooting 1.5C climate target more damaging than we thought: study

image.altText: a police car outside a unit complex with red and white tape

props.synopsis: A 37-year-old person has died after they were allegedly stabbed in the chest on Monday night. A 34-year-old man believed to be related to them has been charged with murder.

title.children: Man, 34, charged with murder over fatal stabbing in Darwin's northern suburbs

image.altText: Close up picture of a woman

props.synopsis: At just 23, Charen has lived on the streets, navigated addiction and been in and out of prison and rehab. She's now participating in a six-month program that's providing a successful alternative to prison for many.

title.children: In this custody 'camp', incarcerated women wear their own clothes and get tailored rehabilitation

image.altText: Two cyclists ride across the desert

props.synopsis: With no support crew or sponsor these two teenagers have spent more than 280 days on the road negotiating floodwaters, bushfires, and running out of supplies as they cross the most remote parts of Australia.

title.children: Teen twitchers raise $100k for Timor-Leste school by cycling around Australia

image.altText: A family of four embrace in outback Australia

props.synopsis: Outback tourism operators are feeling the squeeze as soaring costs and increasing global competition cut into visitor numbers.

title.children: 'Why are we waiting for retirement?': This family sold their home to experience outback Australia

image.altText: Anthony Albanese wears a dark suit, smiles, and shakes hands with Li Qiang who is in a black suit

props.synopsis: It will be his fifth meeting with Li Qiang, and his second in only a few months.

title.children: Anthony Albanese will meet Chinese Premier Li Qiang on the sidelines of ASEAN summit

image.altText: A woman wearing a dark green hijab and blazer stands in a grass field, serious expression on her face

props.synopsis: Fatima Payman's new political party may not be troubling Labor, but it still has plenty of other headaches to worry about.

title.children: Fatima Payman's big reveal of her new political party has done little to trouble Labor

image.altText: Special forces soldier

props.synopsis: Questions are being raised about how alleged war crimes by the Australian Defence Forces are investigated, following the response to the Brereton inquiry.

title.children: Why investigating the alleged war crimes of Australian soldiers is proving so difficult

image.altText: A dark-haired woman wearing a black jacket staring directly at the camera

props.synopsis: The ACT Greens defend their vetting process after admitting to knowing about a candidate's blog post comparing September 11 mastermind Osama bin Laden to Jesus Christ.

title.children: ACT Greens vetting process in question after candidate’s blog post about terrorist leader Bin Laden surfaced

image.altText: A blue sign with white writing that reads Nobel Prize in Chemistry 2024.

props.synopsis: The academy said one of the discoveries being recognised fulfils "a 50-year-old dream of predicting protein structures from their amino acid sequences".

title.children: Scientists David Baker, Demis Hassabis and John Jumper win Nobel Prize in Chemistry for 'predicting protein structures'

image.altText: A red hammer in a circle on a green background on the side of a building.

props.synopsis: Bunnings is Australia's most trusted brand. But allegations the hardware chain has been abusing its market power have prompted a Senate inquiry, that is set to scrutinise the market power of many large format retailers.

title.children: Concerns suppliers to Bunnings and PetStock won't speak to Senate inquiry for fear of losing contracts

image.altText: A middle-aged woman in a purple jacket gestures with her hands as she speaks at a press conference.

props.synopsis: Retirement village residents and their families have backed calls for tougher regulation of the sector, with one saying contracts should carry a cigarette-style financial health warning and another saying the industry is a "black hole".

title.children: Daughter of former retirement village resident calls for 'financial health warning' on village contracts

image.altText: A man with grey hair and glasses raises his hand

props.synopsis: Timor-Leste's president Jose Ramos-Horta has sharply criticised exploitation in Australia's Pacific labour scheme, warning that unscrupulous employers are over-charging workers from his country for accommodation and transport.

title.children: Timor-Leste president slams exploitation in Australia's PALM scheme, cites excessive living costs

image.altText: Ken McCallum

props.synopsis: MI5 director general Ken McCallum says Britain is experiencing a staggering rise in assassination attempts and other crimes by Russia and Iran.

title.children: Britain's intelligence agency says Russia is trying to create 'mayhem' in the UK

image.altText: New Zealand flag in front of civic buildings

props.synopsis: As Australians await stronger signals that a rates reprieve is imminent here, across the Tasman, New Zealand's central bank has again taken the knife to its key interest rate.

title.children: New Zealand 'doubles down' on interest rates retreat with more aggressive cut

image.altText: Four people in camo trekking up a grassy area.

props.synopsis: Ember, Jayda, and Maverick disappeared with their father into New Zealand's mountain ranges in 2021 — they've just been seen together for the first time in years.

title.children: Tom Phillips took his children and vanished into New Zealand's mountains three years ago. They've just been spotted

image.altText: Barricades at a bridge Korean writing on it.

props.synopsis: North Korea's military said it will "completely cut off roads and railways" linked to South Korea and "fortify the relevant areas of our side with strong defence structures."

title.children: North Korea to 'permanently' shut border with South Korea

image.altText: A young man in a suit with short hair and sculpted facial hair smiles happily for a portrait.

props.synopsis: IBAC investigators say a former mayor of Moonee Valley City Council repeatedly accepted drugs in exchange for progressing property applications.

title.children: 'God status': Mayor repeatedly accepted drugs in exchange for planning help, finds IBAC report

image.altText: Putin, wearing an ear piece, looks over to his shoulder to the blurred profile of Trump closer in frame

props.synopsis: A new book by a Washington Post reporter claims the Republican nominee trying to return to the White House has had ongoing contact with Vladimir Putin.

title.children: New book claims Trump posted COVID tests to Putin in 2020

image.altText: Apartment buildings from a distance.

props.synopsis: Australian Bureau of Statistics data shows approvals for dwellings in Australia has fallen 6.1 per cent, with the biggest drop for approvals in medium and high-density homes. Housing experts say the decline is being caused by rising construction costs and increased risk.

title.children: Dwelling approvals fall in Australia as costs, labour shortages slow approvals for new homes

image.altText: An illustration of a young person talking to a police officer

props.synopsis: In the midst of a spike in Victorian youth crime, researchers say young people with intellectual disabilities are going unsupported and overlooked in the criminal justice system.

title.children: 'I was just saying yes, yes, yes': Young people with intellectual disabilities over-represented in justice system

image.altText: Sheila Raymond and family members

props.synopsis: Sheila Thurlow's family is calling for an inquest into her death at a Brisbane hospital after she was injected with 1,000 times the intended dose of morphine.

title.children: Nurse 'Googled' hospital procedure night before woman was given 1,000 times the intended level of morphine

image.altText: Illustration of autonomous self-driving cars.

props.synopsis: A Choice investigation has found most of Australia's popular car brands collect and share "driver data", ranging from braking patterns to video footage and voice recognition information.

title.children: Cars are data-harvesting machines. These brands share your personal information

image.altText: Satellite image of Hurricane Milton on approach to US

props.synopsis: Hurricane Milton is set to make landfall on Florida's west coast as a powerful and extremely dangerous category five storm.

title.children: Millions in Florida warned homes could become coffins when Hurricane Milton hits

image.altText: Reece raises his arms as he crossed the Melbourne Marathon finish line, with the time 02:14:35 on a screen above him.

props.synopsis: Reece Edwards had enough saved for a house deposit when he was 20, but spent the money on other experiences instead. While some might see that as a "financial disaster", he has a different take.

title.children: The elite runner who is such a diligent saver, his 'guilty splurge' is a weekly banh mi

image.altText: Jake Stringer of the Bombers celebrates kicking a goal

props.synopsis: Polarising forward Jake Stringer could be on the move from Essendon to the GWS Giants. Catch up on day three of the AFL trade period with our blog.

title.children: Essendon legend's harsh truth to Jake Stringer as Giants eye trade deal — as it happened

image.altText: Australian actor Hugo Weaving with a white beard smiling with a santa het.

props.synopsis: The trailer features Hugo Weaving, a cameo from rapper Briggs, and a dollop of tomato sauce for sweetness and that extra tang.

title.children: First look at Christmas film How To Make Gravy, based on Paul Kelly's iconic song
